title: Latina/o immigrants are routinely blamed for Black unemployment and poverty. With some notable exceptions, however, such as the janitorial industry, evidence suggests that Latina/o immigration has had a mixed impact. For instance, Ong and Valenzuela found that while Latina/o immigration affected Black joblessness (but not earnings), equally important was the role of institutional racism and employer discrimination. Paul Ong and Abel Valenzuela, “The Labor Market: Immigrant Effects and Racial Disparities,” in Waldinger and Bozorgmehr, Ethnic Los Angeles, 165–91.
